Author: Cory Woodroof
Review: The monster action was actually pretty thrilling, but the film doesn’t do some of its main characters a lot of favors with the script.

Author: Rebecca Johnson
Review: The action is frequent and engaging, the CGI looks fantastic, the story-line is captivating, and the movie is paced well and rounded off with an epic final battle.

Author: Manuel São Bento
Review: More action sequences (visible and in daylight), more monsters, and a visually stunning Kong. However, most of the runtime stills belong to the humans who, unfortunately, are nowhere near to being as compelling as in the previous film.

Author: Keith Garlington
Review: It’s a well made, fast-paced monster movie with far more craft behind its presentation and storytelling than you would expect.

Author: Brian Eggert
Review: Vogt-Roberts, with his highbrow film references and postmodern affectations, wants Kong: Skull Island to be more ambitious and thoughtful than it is.

Author: David Gonzalez
Review: While Kong is impressive, his counterparts on the islands are just as visually stunning.

Author: Don Shanahan
Review: If you want a rip-roaring roller coaster with no strings, rules, or heavy gravitas attached, youve come to the right place.

Author: Paul M. Bradshaw
Review: Dialogue aside, this is a film that provides some supersized thrills.

Author: Nicole Carpenter
Review: It's a ridiculous movie - in a good way - that just hit right.

Author: Matt Brunson
Review: The fear is that these shared universes will become the norm, leading to that awkward point when, say, the men from Moonlight team up with the La La Land lovebirds to prevent Paul Blart from destroying a shopping mall owned by the Tyrell Corporation.

Author: Jordy Sirkin
Review: Kong: Skull Island once again brings the famed creature back to the big screen with classic monster movie magic.

Author: Rudie Obias
Review: Kong: Skull Island is a very serviceable popcorn movie for March, but it could've been more memorable and lasting. I found myself forgetting most of the movie once I stepped into the lobby to leave the theater after it was over.

Author: Mike Massie
Review: Bogging down the time for breathtaking gargantuan clashes is an abundance of characters, most of whom have no reason for being in the film.

Author: Kelechi Ehenulo
Review: Rebooted to coincide with the shared monsters universe set by Godzilla back in 2014, Kong: Skull Island certainly delivers on the excitement but is let down by other factors.

Author: Damond Fudge
Review: Kong: Skull Island is a magnificent and impressive giant monster epic, that also feels very small and personal at the same time.

Author: Ricardo Gallegos
Review: If you want to see King Kong kick ass, this movie is for you. [Full review in Spanish]

Author: Brent McKnight
Review: Individual moments are incredibly fun and exhilarating, and the giant monsters are precisely as giant and monstrous as you can hope. But too many others are tedious and painfully dull.

Author: Avaryl Halley
Review: It's weird. It's like Full Metal Jacket with King Kong.

Author: Andrew Galdi
Review: This movie is a mess in so many ways.

Author: Steven Prokopy
Review: More Asian monster movie than American giant-animal attack film, this movie is rich and unfiltered entertainment.

Author: Dan Scully
Review: This is a movie which is all about fun and spectacle. And it delivers. What more could you want?

Author: Tim Brennan
Review: Tom Hiddleston is supremely confident, and Brie Larson wants to take an unforgettable picture. Everybody is fine.

Author: Douglas Davidson
Review: Loud, violent, and just ridiculous enough to warrant a return to Skull Island as soon as the credits finish rolling, ladies and gentlemen, for your utter delight and pleasure, Vogt-Roberts presents: Kong: Skull Island.

Author: Sarah Knight Adamson
Review: Kong: Skull Island is a ton of fun...however, I don't think upgrading to 3D is necessary-I saw it in 2D and was still blown away.

Author: Chris McCoy
Review: A lot of stuff happens on Skull Island, but none of it makes much sense, so there's no emotional movement.

Author: Julian Lytle
Review: Podcast review

Author: Mark H. Harris
Review: As for the movie itself, it's a pretty mess, full of clichéd, overly explanatory, blockbustery action dialogue.

Author: Leslie Combemale
Review: Overall, Kong: Skull Island is a worthy popcorn flick where you can easily cheer for both human and creature.

Author: Nicholas Bell
Review: No one's taking any real risks with Kong: Skull Island except to promise the return of more monster mash-ups.

Author: Linda and Al Lerner
Review: It's well directed by Vogt-Roberts, well scripted and shot.

Author: Josh Wilding
Review: Setting the benchmark for 2017's blockbusters, Kong: Skull Island is visually stunning, thrilling from start to finish and a triumphant big screen return for King Kong. Be sure to stay after the credits!

Author: Kate Rodger
Review: Wasn't even close to a home run for me, but still plenty going on for most audiences to sink their rainy day teeth into.

Author: Jorge Loser
Review: An exhausting journey without dramatic impact, neither in the beliefs of its heroes nor in the apparitions of the protagonist animal. [Full Review in Spanish]

Author: Allison Rose
Review: I suspect we will have two factions - the 2005 version of King Kong fans and the Skull Island King Kong version fans. Regardless, the movie is entertaining and has a lot going for it.

Author: Karl Delossantos
Review: Not only is the plot subpar, the characters feel like they're made to die and the ones that have some purpose are so dull that you wouldn't even care if they were gone.

Author: Dominic Griffin
Review: This is franchise filmmaking at its least fussy. Legendary Pictures has a sandbox full of iconic monsters to play with, so they're going to fill that box up with sharp performers and talented helmers to make violent merriment for a couple of hours...

Author: Ryan Syrek
Review: Watching Skull Island is like eating a buffet of great individual dishes that never comes together into one coherent meal.

Author: Mattie Lucas
Review: A silly dumbing down of the Kong mythos, complete with a moronic sense of a humor and a complete misuse of its talented cast

Author: Kaitlyn Booth
Review: Longtime fans of Kong will find a lot to love here.

Author: Andrew Kendall
Review: Try to remember the name of any character a day after, and you probably won't. You're not supposed to. The film does not care for any of them. Neither do we.

Author: Dan Murrell
Review: The monster stuff was great and the human stuff was just good enough for me to not jump off board with the movie.

Author: Rachel Wagner
Review: Even Kong is underwritten in this film.

Author: Bertie Archer
Review: A reboot with refinement, this is exactly the story (and movie) Kong needed to break out of the celluloid cage he's been kept in.

Author: Deborah Cornelious
Review: Kong Skull Island is a visual treat for the most part.

Author: Allen Adams
Review: This offering is monster magic; it's essentially a B-movie made with an A-plus budget. It is big and broad, filled with huge action set pieces and moments of humor and surprising pathos.

Author: Rahul Desai
Review: Each time the camera cuts to any of these faces, they appear as if they were high school jocks feigning danger in their annual freshman-year stage play.

Author: Doug Jamieson
Review: Grab your popcorn and just enjoy yourself.

Author: Amanda Greever
Review: Jordan Vogt-Roberts exhibits a deft directorial hand, balancing different interests, different styles, different tones.

Author: Sarah Cartland
Review: Your monster enemy's monster enemy is your monster friend in "Kong: Skull Island", as is the CGI which is genuinely thrilling. But overall it's bloated and overlong, with so many characters running around it feels like the last night of "Big Brother".

Author: Colby Bryant
Review: While he doesn't carry the pathos ... (of) Caesar of the Planet of the Apes films, ... Kong's a full on action hero here, laying the smack down in ways that make you cheer.

Author: Di Golding
Review: Director Jordan Vogt-Roberts sets a tone that balances between visual awe, and dry humour... all while having fun with tropes and a none-too-subtle homage to Apocalypse Now.

Author: Li Lai
Review: Although Kong: Skull Island doesn't even pass the Bechdel Test, it's a relief to watch a silly action romp without overt misogyny or cringeworthy racism.

Author: Matt Oakes
Review: 'Kong' is king-sized entertainment, a riveting spectacle showcase that races from dizzying set piece to set piece, fastened by standout technical work across the board.

Author: Bob Chipman
Review: I just couldn't shake the feeling that I would've enjoyed this even more if it really was just a guy in a dumpy gorilla suit stomping around on miniature sets.

Author: Harris Dang
Review: Kong: Skull Island is a lot of fun, with many spectacular monster battles, a likeable ensemble cast, outstanding visual splendour and a standout performance from John C. Reilly.

Author: Molly Henery
Review: Kong: Skull Island is my favorite giant monster film since Cloverfield (2008).

Author: Zaki Hasan
Review: This is a movie that's smart enough to know when to be silly.

Author: Sean Mulvihill
Review: Despite its numerous and noticeable flaws, it's impossible not to be entertained by the lavish spectacle on display in Kong: Skull Island even if it lacks the heart and emotion that it aims for in certain scenes.

Author: Jennifer Heaton
Review: It's a marked improvement over Godzilla by simply not taking itself as seriously, focusing instead on what a giant monster movie should be: entertaining.

Author: Nguyên Lê
Review: With a banquet of beasts, stylish beasts-versus-humans set pieces and gruesome deaths on both sides, Kong: Skull Island is a creature feature hell bent on thrilling its audience.

Author: Alan French
Review: You know what really makes the film work? When the giant ape monster destroys stuff. And he does not disappoint when given the chance to destroy.

Author: Rendy Jones
Review: With effective visuals, brilliant action sequences, and masterful direction by Vogt-Roberts who thoroughly proves why Kong remains King of creature feature films.

Author: Pat Padua
Review: Although its script is uninspired, the movie satisfies a basic cinematic need: the need to watch big monsters fight each other-a lot!

Author: Abbie Bernstein
Review: Kong: Skull Island is big, fast, mostly solid and appealing in its nostalgia for the big monster movies of yore. It's a very good one of what it is.

Author: Akhil Arora
Review: The film's evoking of its anti-war counterparts falls flat, and feels hollow, much like the island itself.

Author: Pamela Powell
Review: When you have the comedic talent of John C. Reilly and the intensity of Samuel L. Jackson, it's OK to have yet another remake of "King Kong."

Author: Mae Abdulbaki
Review: "Kong: Skull Island" isn't the most horrible film you'll ever see, but it's lack of imagination and dullness is most definitely apparent.

Author: Glenn Heath Jr.
Review: Turning Skull Island into a proxy war for Vietnam sounds good on paper, but the dire implications of America's devastating foreign policies deserves more complex treatment than the film can muster.

Author: Stephanie Cooke
Review: The story is great for what this movie is. It doesn't drag, it provides you with what you want (Tom Hiddleston and also the giant gorilla).

Author: Britany Murphy
Review: Director, Jordan Vogt-Roberts definitely knows how to helm your routine action flick.

Author: Leah Sydney
Review: Kong,... is most definitely a gloried B-movie, and it smartly knows exactly what lane it's supposed to be in, which shows from the first scene.

Author: Glenn Dunks
Review: This incarnation's weird Apocalypse Now vibes are an odd fit...

Author: Kevin A. Ranson
Review: While not a perfect film and a bit gratuitous focusing upon Ms. Larson's filthy yet ever-tightening tank top, we get a better-than-average ensemble story thanks to a clever castaway.

Author: Oggs Cruz
Review: Kong: Skull Island, while never abandoning the need to astound and create wonders out of the classic beast overpowering humans plot, shapes its drama more diligently around the skewed affairs of its human characters rather than the titular monster.

Author: Alison Rowat
Review: This star-laden action drama is proof that more money and gizmos do not necessarily make for a bigger thrill ride... a picture that has plenty of crash and bang but little in the way of emotional wallop.

Author: Shaun Munro
Review: At once passably entertaining and undeniably disappointing, the latest attempt to re-imagine King Kong...misses almost as much as it hits, but propelled by the titular beast's sheer mythic power, it just barely scrapes a pass regardless.

Author: Daniel de Partearroyo
Review: This Kong deserved a monument. [Full review in Spanish]

Author: Ruben Peralta Rigaud
Review: It is a film that does not demand much explanation... and in one way or another this makes it attractive. [Full review in Spanish]

Author: Andre Meadows
Review: It captures the spirit of a war movie. It's very much shot like a war movie, and that gives it some style and charm.

Author: Rick Marshall
Review: 'Kong: Skull Island' makes the giant ape great again

Author: Jeremy Jahns
Review: The pacing was choppy, and it was shoddy and all over the place...when Kong was on screen, it was really cool to watch, but in the end it didn't pay off.

Author: Steph Cozza
Review: Sam Jackson and John C Riley definitely stole the show.

Author: James Plath
Review: Best. Kong. Ever.

Author: Carl Kozlowski
Review: This is one movie that absolutely demands to be seen on the big screen, preferably with the full glasses effect, yet is solid enough entertainment to stand on its own in 2D as well.

Author: Erick Ortiz
Review: Kong: The Skull Island is not as emotional, or epic, as its predecessors. [Full review in Spanish]

Author: Al Hoff
Review: What the film lacks in plot, tension, dialogue and fully realized characters, it makes up for with some fantastic visuals.

Author: Jason Guerrasio
Review: What starts out as a potentially fun and cliche-less way to do an action movie turns into another watered-down origin story of a franchise.

Author: Robert Kojder
Review: It's relentless in its catastrophic, seismic destruction (even containing moderately interesting and likable human characters), and anyone who isn't taken aback by it should check their pulse

Author: Courtney Howard
Review: That's not to say there's nothing good here. There is - it just could've been so much better.

Author: Danielle Solzman
Review: It may not match the original classic but the fast-paced story holds its own.

Author: Kristen Lopez
Review: There's life in the old ape yet, but he sinks like the Titanic.

Author: Nazareno Brega
Review: The most interesting thing about the Jordan Vogt-Roberts film is not in the fable but in the entertainment produced by each action sequence. [Full review in Spanish]

Author: Michael A. Smith
Review: And while Kong isn't all over the film he appears enough to remind you who's King. The action is intense and the special effects are well done.

Author: Matthew Bond
Review: Kong: Skull Island is a film that underwhelms in nearly every department.

Author: Jordan Ruimy
Review: KING KONG: SKULL ISLAND is an entertaining B-movie with first-rate special effects and expertly staged action

Author: Sarah Marrs
Review: But the MVP is John C. Reilly as Marlow, who was stranded on Skull Island after crash-landing there in World War II. Reilly 100% understands the movie he's in and every bit of Kong that works that doesn't involve monsters works because of Reilly.

Author: Joanne Soh
Review: The fights between Kong and his foes are epic and exciting - enough to make this creature feature just that little bit more special.

Author: George M. Thomas
Review: Kong: Skull Island revives the monster flick with humor, a decent story, and modern effects without sacrificing any fun.

Author: Keeva Stratton
Review: Perhaps we have become impatient as an audience and directors are no longer keen to hold back, but sadly I feel the film was poorer for its immediate unveiling of the myriad of monsters.

Author: Tim Brayton
Review: A truly remarkable number of actors seem to be doing, if not their career-worst work, then at least work that they're well-capable of bettering.

Author: Adam Starkey
Review: This is a generic, tonally awkward monster showcase which forgets about both charm and heart, in its humans and King Kong himself.

Author: Robert Denerstein
Review: It's fun, even if the movie ultimately exhausts itself.

Author: K. Austin Collins
Review: Kong: Skull Island isn't a B-movie - but with its intentionally bad writing and jarring lack of cohesion, it lamely pretends to be one.

Author: Carlos Díaz Reyes
Review: Filled with action and good visuals, this film is hilarious. [Full review in Spanish]

Author: Eleanor Ringel Cater
Review: "Kong: Skull Island" isn't going to change your life. Nor can it hold a candle to the 1933 original. But there are some good thrills to be had here - and some good fun, too.

Author: Angie Han
Review: The humans, meanwhile, are largely left to stare in awe.

Author: Brandy McDonnell
Review: Like an ape nimbly traversing the trees, Kong: Skull Island boasts excellent equilibrium for such a sprawling movie.

Author: Julia Alexander
Review: Kong: Skull Island gets what so many monster movies before it get wrong: There is humanity in the creatures, even if they can seem gigantic and monstrous at first.

Author: Renuka Vyavahare
Review: If you don't mind some shallow, video game-esque entertainment, this one doesn't disappoint.

Author: Michael Sragow
Review: What's fatal to this movie is that it lacks visionary gusto.

Author: David N. Butterworth
Review: "Kong: Numbskull Island" is more like it.

Author: David Nusair
Review: An especially awful Hollywood blockbuster...

Author: Orlando Maldonado
Review: A game of cat and mouse, in which the rodents are replaced by helicopters falling in pairs at the hands of an enraged Kong. [Full review in Spanish]

Author: Matthew Pejkovic
Review: Perfectly treads the line between big budget VFX cinema & b-grade exploitation.

Author: Mario P. Székely
Review: What could have been a suspense film, ends up being a B cinema production, with lowly plotted characters, stupid motivations and a Kong who still urges a girlfriend to reveal his nobility. [Full review in Spanish]

Author: Ernesto Diezmartinez
Review: The film has colorful special effects that, in fact, stop being colorful when one realizes that they are nothing more than that: special effects without a story. A disaster. [Full review in Spanish]

Author: Stephen Silver
Review: Skull Island, for a lot of reasons, shouldn't work-until, suddenly, it does. (Splice Today)

Author: Cole Smithey
Review: "Kong: Skull Island" is a neutered adventure movie without any soul, or balls.

Author: Walter Chaw
Review: At the end of it all, the picture's only real saving grace is John C. Reilly as a castaway WWII airman who lands a few one-liners the way that only Reilly can, while off-setting the general shittiness of the rest of the human interaction.

Author: Christopher Orr
Review: Kong: Skull Island is just good enough-the sharp allusions, the moments of wit and warmth supplied by Reilly's long-abandoned airman-to make one wish it were better.

Author: Pete Vonder Haar
Review: Humans monkey with nature; giant ape goes bananas, wishing they would lemur him alone.

Author: Israel Acosta Aroche
Review: A film with a fresh perspective and great action sequences that will be able to entertain anyone. [Full review in Spanish]

Author: James Kendrick
Review: primarily feels repetitious, rather than thrilling or awe-inspiring, with the same basic threats reworked over and over again to dwindling effect

Author: John Beifuss
Review: Jettisons the timeless beauty-and-the-beast tragedy of the 1933 masterpiece for a borrowed Vietnam allegory...

Author: Jason Bailey
Review: I've got no quarrel with a good, goofy monster movie - I'm the guy who liked 'The Great Wall.' But that film at least felt bound by a singular vision, by a director and his personality. 'Kong: Skull Island' is spare parts, held together with Scotch tape.

Author: Glenn Lovell
Review: Not only the most exhilarating e-ticket ride since 'Mad Max Fury Road,' it's almost as exciting as the RKO original, thanks to expertly orchestrated cliff-hangers and the scariest CG beasties since 'Jurassic Park'

Author: Evan Griffin
Review: Just because you get to see a ton of the giant monster that supposedly stars in the movie doesn't necessarily make it great.

Author: Ed Whitfield
Review: The story, unencumbered by character building, is just one scene after another.

Author: Charles Koplinski
Review: "Skull Island" an epic monster mash.

Author: Margot Harrison
Review: The film is at its best when it sweeps us into the terror of confronting giants.

Author: Dan Webster
Review: The great ape called Kong first hit the big screen in 1933. IMAX technology has been around since 1970. Now, in 2017, the two have joined forces, and the result almost makes a good movie. Well, half a good movie.

Author: J. Olson
Review: Vogt-Roberts and his editor indiscriminately wallop us with action, darting from character to character and scene to scene, none of it making any impact at all.

Author: Damien Straker
Review: Despite the enormity of its scale and the detail of its creature effects, Kong's story lacks imagination and sags at its midpoint.

Author: Bob Grimm
Review: Kong looks great...Tom Hiddleston looks silly.

Author: Kelly Vance
Review: The big guy actually functions as the balance of nature on Skull Island. If he dies, the place becomes a Jurassic Park-style resort attraction. So the world needs Kong.

Author: Katherine Monk
Review: The result lands somewhere between camp and slick action... For the most part, it feels like a joyride as the director pulls donuts in the parking lot before making it onto the highway of storytelling.

Author: Peter Suderman
Review: Skull Island is packed with stunning, innovative effects work. But that effects work is also a form of consistently excellent acting, one that contrasts with the generally lackluster human characters Kong is surrounded by.

Author: Tony Macklin
Review: Kong: Skull Island wouldn't be what it is without Apocalypse Now.

Author: Emily Wheeler
Review: Kong: Skull Island is fleeting entertainment, but given its massive budget and the audience's predisposition to Kong, that's not a terribly impressive feat.

Author: Jay Horton
Review: Skull Island replaces Age of Discovery heroics with wartime ambience.

Author: David 'Mad Dog' Bradley
Review: The whole bunch virtually run straight into Kong, who doesn't take kindly to all the bombs and helicopter-swoopings (and Black Sabbath's Paranoid) in a sequence that proves spectacular indeed.

Author: Dave Crewe
Review: My real gripe with the film isn't its modest ambitions, but that it's not consistently fun enough.

Author: Tara Thorne
Review: Bizarrely entertaining, but not recommended.

Author: James Hadfield
Review: The film only really comes into its element when the beasts start brawling, but still -- what brawls.

Author: Mark R. Leeper
Review: There are a lot of "What-the-heck--Oh-my- god!" reactions. There are moments that are a lot of fun.

Author: Craig Mathieson
Review: It has a barbed sense of humour, a thankful disbelief in military might and a sense of scale that comes with a mocking physicality. Swallowed whole or swatted like flies, human beings are insignificant distractions in this lost world.

Author: Luis Fernando Galván
Review: Kong: Skull Island isn't scary or frightening, neither excites nor surprises, it just entertains. Will that be enough? [Full review in Spanish]

Author: Erick Estrada
Review: An entertaining adventure where the nonsense abuse us that we don't resist the temptation of that pill that we swallowed as soon as the initial credits finished. [Full review in Spanish]

Author: Sebastian Zavala Kahn
Review: A fun movie full of monsters; those who know little about the original story will have lots of fun, while the purist fanatics will probably be bothered by all the changes made to the character. [Full review in Spanish]

Author: José Martín
Review: If we don't get carried away by false expectations of transcendence that are never fulfilled, the film is easily enjoyed. [Full review in Spanish]

Author: Emmanuel Báez
Review: A class B movie with a budget class A where everything is about the show, and with the ideas clear, it is difficult to fall into distractions, since at all times there is something new to enjoy. [Full review in Spanish]

Author: Robert Roten
Review: The visual effects and the acting are solid. There is also plenty of action and the pace is fast. This is basically a popcorn movie with some humor in it. With all the craziness these days, a big, goofy action movie like this really hits the spot.

Author: Jason Di Rosso
Review: Thrilling, funny, and occasionally sublime.

Author: Sarah Ward
Review: It mightn't always be smart and logical, and its rarely unpredictable, but Kong: Skull Island is consistently enjoyable in the giant-creature-threatens-humanity tradition.

Author: Hilary A White
Review: Concentrate on the magical CGI rendering, the surprisingly lush and tasteful cinematography and a nicely dotty John C Reilly as a Pacific War castaway and you'll have a ball.

Author: Bill Arceneaux
Review: A perfect example of what is perceived as "escapism."

Author: Marija Djurovic
Review: It might be silly, but Skull Island is a fast-paced and entertaining ball of fun.

Author: Luke Goodsell
Review: Skull Island manages to hold [its] precarious balance of haphazard social commentary and B-movie thrills for an admirable distance, assisted immensely by the levity of the screenplay and performances.

Author: Sergio López Aguirre
Review: A thrilling journey commanded by one-dimensional humans, in the hands of Tom Hiddleston and Brie Larson, to discover exciting beasts. Full review in Spanish]

Author: Adrián Ruiz
Review: The film has all that a blockbuster requires, a multistelar cast, amazing effects and locations, as well as a new twist to tell the story of an iconic character. [Full review in Spanish]

Author: Luis Martínez
Review: The director manages to compose a chaotic fable where everything fits: from war movies to simple comedy. [Full review in Spanish]

Author: John Serba
Review: There's no mistaking "Kong" for anything but gregarious, sometimes goofy entertainment.

Author: Dennis Schwartz
Review: One of the better monster films.

Author: Dana Barbuto
Review: You don't need to be familiar with Kongs past to enjoy this reimagining - it's neither a sequel nor prequel. You just need to be a lover of action-adventure.

Author: Elias Savada
Review: Kong: Skull Island is an action-packed Darwinian fairy tale, full of digitally appealing assets in a beautiful setting. Are you ready for your close-up, Mr. Kong?

Author: Charlotte O'Sullivan
Review: The CGI Kong is cool.

Author: Henry Fitzherbert
Review: Kong: Skull Island is an overblown monster movie that constitutes just shy of two hours of meaningless spectacle.

Author: Wendy Ide
Review: Enjoyable enough, if a little overblown.

Author: Jason Best
Review: A genre blending fantasy adventure that combines creature-feature spectacle and grunts-in-the-jungle thrills: King Kong meets Apocalypse Now.

Author: Matt Looker
Review: There are so many money-shots in this movie, it has already grossed enough cash to purchase a lifetime's supply of bananas for a real-life King Kong.

Author: Steven D. Greydanus
Review: Look, if you want to see King Kong duking it out with creatures that are literally called "Skullcrawlers," or locked in battle with a giant octopus...this film is your huckleberry.

Author: Jim Schembri
Review: There's some mandatory enviro-messaging amidst all the mayhem - respect the wild, man does not have dominion over the earth, etc - but this really is a giant serving of joyful, disposable blockbuster mulch, full of lovely, mega-sized beasts.

Author: Tom Glasson
Review: Big, dumb and fun, Kong is an exhilarating, old-school action romp.

Author: Daniel M. Kimmel
Review: So grab the popcorn and sit back like a kid at a Saturday matinee. Kong: Skull Island is the real deal.

Author: Rashid Irani
Review: Unfortunately director Jordan Vogt-Roberts, making the leap to a big-budget blockbuster after his indie debut The Kings of Summer (2013), can't match the white-knuckle excitement of the iconic black-and-white original.

Author: Nandini Ramnath
Review: Vogt-Roberts films the predictable adventure with tremendous flair, and cinematographer Larry Fong's washed-out colour palette elevates the humdrum "make war not love" tone of the proceedings. The ape towers over the film, as it has in every version.

Author: Susan Granger
Review: A spectacular, fun-filled creature-feature, concluding with a post-credit franchise promotion...

Author: Andy Lea
Review: This is very unusual blockbuster - a Vietnam war flick, a comedy and an old-fashioned creature feature in one monstrously entertaining package. It's bananas but brilliant.

Author: Ed Power
Review: Action-packed and irony-free, Skull Island is the very best sort of monkey business.

Author: Eric Kohn
Review: There's enough material out there to fuel a string of reboots, but the swing toward diminishing returns has already begun.

Author: Annlee Ellingson
Review: A rip-roaring monster movie with exhilarating action, weighty dialogue, nostalgic visuals and a wicked sense of humor.

Author: Kirk Baird
Review: It may be Beauty who killed the Beast in the original King Kong, but in Kong: Skull Island it's the lackluster screenplay that takes down this not-so-great ape.

Author: Ray Pride
Review: Kaiju a-go-go: Hyper-scaled B movie set in 1973, in the waning days of U. S. days in the Vietnam War, that appropriates the DNA of dozens of other movies for a crisp burst of grandiosely-scaled goofiness.

Author: Todd Jorgenson
Review: ... positions itself as an origin story about the massive ape, but really is just another excuse to revive the venerable movie monster for another big-budget confrontation with some hapless Homo sapiens.

Author: Barry Paris
Review: However much a mashup of its predecessors and of Jurassic Park, Apocalypse Now, Miss Saigon and Journey to Center of the Earth, it moves fast and it marks the entertaining return of cinema's most enduring and endearing beast.

Author: Ilan Preskovsky
Review: Kong: Skull Island is far from the major return we might have hoped for of one of cinema's most memorable monsters, but it's bright and rollickingly fun.

Author: Christopher Lawrence
Review: Reilly is jangling with pure electricity ... You'd need something a whole lot more interesting than anything else going on in "Skull Island" to pry your eyes away from him.

Author: Beth Accomando
Review: Kong: Skull Island is first and foremost a monster movie, and if you are going just for the monster, then "Skull Island" delivers the goods.

Author: Eric Melin
Review: It embodies that American Barnum impulse the original satirized, hoping that a heavy dose of violence and a familiar entity in the title will be enough to pack 'em in. Behold the sad, cynical Kong: First Blood Part II.

Author: Josh Terry
Review: This is a fun, fun movie. It's also a violent movie - the high enough body count and gore should convince parents to leave the kids at home - even though the violence comes in a frequently comic PG-13 CGI-style.

Author: Armond White
Review: Designed, like all movie franchises, to fulfill the Millennial urge for escapist entertainment, Kong: Skull Island is the blockbuster as junky postmodern bread and circuses.

Author: Alan Zilberman
Review: Kong: Skull Island is admirable in its desire to get right into the good stuff.

Author: Bernard Boo
Review: Kong: Skull Island has a lot going for it, but what it gets really right is how it captures the unadulterated, intoxicating joy of watching the mighty Kong smash things to itty bitty pieces.

Author: Scott D. Pierce
Review: Kong sets out to be a first-rate monster movie, and it succeeds.

Author: Rich Cline
Review: It's a ripping adventure, cleverly directed by Jordan Vogt-Roberts to resemble a snarky Apocalypse Now remake with added gigantic beasts. And the eclectic cast makes sure that there's plenty of comedy, villainy and heroics to draw the audience in.

Author: Blake Howard
Review: "Kong: Skull Island" is big action film, with big ideas with a deep ensemble that becomes something more than big dumb fun.

Author: Stephen Romei
Review: It's the inclusion of historical references, and literary ones, that make this film engaging, despite its faults.

Author: Matthew Lickona
Review: It's fun to watch the [monsters] in action, but on the human side, the film is clumsily written, over-cast and underacted, with only frustrated soldier Samuel L. Jackson striking the right tone of crazy amid the chaos.

Author: James Verniere
Review: Mostly dumb, but also fun. Apocalypse KONG.

Author: Kanin Srimaneekulroj
Review: Kong: Skull Island offers enough interesting visual set pieces that it becomes easy to ignore many of its flaws.

Author: Sean Burns
Review: There's a word for what's missing: direction.

Author: Rob Vaux
Review: It does more by doing less: enhancing the pulp origins of Kong's world and focusing on having a good time instead of reminding us how much better its immortal predecessor was.

Author: Sara Michelle Fetters
Review: As ludicrous and as unfocused as it all might be, Kong: Skull Island kept me amused for practically every second of its two-hour running time.

Author: Eric D. Snider
Review: Creaky dialogue and questionable story are counteracted by visceral, thrilling scenes of zoological mayhem.

Author: Mathew DeKinder
Review: They've actually managed to elevate the quality quotient by throwing an all-star cast and an effective man vs. nature plotline into the mix. Oh, and a giant ape wailing on huge lizard creatures. Can't forget that.

Author: Neil Rosen
Review: If all you're looking for is visually impressive non-stop action, and you don't care about story, dialogue or characters, then go. But I need a lot more out of a movie.

Author: Randall King
Review: Yes, it's unpretentious, but we're left with the niggling feeling this could have been so much more interesting.

Author: Peter Sobczynski
Review: Fast, furious and insanely entertaining.

Author: Kristen Yoonsoo Kim
Review: You know what they say: go big or go home, and Kong should've gone all out with the thrills in order to, at the very least, make up for the alarming lack of character development or something resembling a decent script.

Author: Mike McGranaghan
Review: The movie knows precisely what it takes to deliver mayhem that makes you smile and lean in so that you can savor every awesomely chaotic second.

Author: Peter Rainer
Review: The action and special effects are mostly first-rate and Vogt-Roberts maintains a vaguely satiric tone that sidesteps schlockiness.

Author: Sandie Angulo Chen
Review: Battles are brutally violent in diverse, '70s-set reboot.

Author: Piers Marchant
Review: What this film does remarkably well is give us a full-bodied Kong that moves and acts in a way that seems utterly befitting a giant of this magnitude.

Author: Amy Nicholson
Review: Creedence Clearwater Revival thrums on the soundtrack - has any '70s movie managed to avoid it? - but when the giant spiders start stomping, Vogt-Roberts earns the right to blast "Run Through the Jungle."

Author: Greg Maki
Review: From the creature design to the cinematography ... to stunning locations in Vietnam, Australia and Hawaii, 'Skull Island' looks amazing ...

Author: Gary Wolcott
Review: Guilty pleasure with two dimensional characters in an equally two dimensional plot that only allows them to be in peril. No beauty and the beast and that's good.

Author: Jeffrey M. Anderson
Review: A well-crafted, intense ride that derides shoot-first, think-later military rationale, and champions curiosity and compassion.

Author: Robert Horton
Review: Hiddleston is a bust as a dashing adventurer ("Stand on a hillside with one leg cocked" seems to be his acting note), and Larson has the shocked look of someone who wins an Oscar and finds out this is her reward.

Author: Rebecca Murray
Review: Kong: Skull Island is basically a prolonged glare-off between the gigantic ape and Samuel L. Jackson as Lieutenant Colonel Packard.

Author: Christian Toto
Review: This Kong is still fiercely territorial, quick to anger and has a weakness for blondes. Oh, and he's surly about American imperialism, too.

Author: Phil Villarreal
Review: Hail to the king, baby.

Author: Kurt Loder
Review: Good grief, Kong again?

Author: Jim Judy
Review: Enjoyable enough for what it is -- an action outing featuring people stuck in a land of enormous, deadly and hungry monsters where Kong is indeed king. (Full Content Review for Parents - Violence, Profanity, etc. - also Available)

Author: Rob Thomas
Review: It's that kind of movie, meant for the biggest screen, the loudest sound system and the slouchiest recliner you can find. The fact that it also features good actors acting? An unexpected big bonus.

Author: Kim Newman
Review: The film doesn't try to compare with the depth and resonance of any given King Kong, because it lacks the tragic last stand.

Author: Roxana Hadadi
Review: Underneath all the giant monster blood and guts, there's little substance in Kong: Skull Island. The slimy viscera, despite the filmmakers' best intentions, stands alone and without impact.

Author: Jonathan W. Hickman
Review: "Kong: Skull Island" is more fun than the last "Godzilla" film but not as engaging.

Author: Steve Crum
Review: Stereotypical in many ways, 'Kong: Skull Island' is great fun to watch, thanks to a literate, savvy script, fine acting, and visuals that should please the most discriminating monster movie fan.

Author: Jeffrey Lyles
Review: At its best, Skull Island delivers colossal big screen mayhem with the big guy standing tall. Could you really ask for anything more?

Author: Barry Hertz
Review: It is the platonic ideal of big, smart-dumb B-movie filmmaking - and, like Kong himself, it must be seen to be believed.

Author: Adam Graham
Review: A fun if muddled monster movie that gets its best jolts from the sheer size of its beasts.

Author: Willie Waffle
Review: Kong: Skull Island is an action movie trying to be a little more sarcastic than that, but they should stick to the action.

Author: Sonny Bunch
Review: Kong: Skull Island has lots of monsters and lots of explosions and lots of scenery chewing, but it has very little in the way of heart or humanity

Author: Sarah Boslaugh
Review: I went to see Kong: Skull Island hoping for some good, dumb fun. Unfortunately, while director Jordan Vogt-Roberts nailed the dumb part, he managed to miss out on the fun.

Author: Rohan Naahar
Review: Despite stunning visuals and a fine cast, Kong: Skull Island is, well, crushingly monkey brained.

Author: Bob Bloom
Review: While "Kong: Skull Island" is visual eye candy, its sophistication and excellence negate the fairy tale-magical quality that endeared the original to generations of filmgoers.

Author: Jeanne Kaplan
Review: The final battle scene between Kong and his mortal nemesis, the Skullcrawler, is magnificent. It is as exciting and nail-biting as anything I've seen on screen. It is beautifully choreographed and ultimately satisfying without being too long --- for once!

Author: David Kaplan
Review: King Kong is as likeable and sympathetic as any of his predecessors. And his battles with the island's predators are spectacularly staged.

Author: Michael Coldwell
Review: So, big sigh of relief, the ape is back in shape and just maybe we have ourselves a franchise. Stick around after the credits for a Kong vs. Everything primer. Bring it on!

Author: Elliott Noble
Review: Thanks to the formidable effects and thumping forward momentum, you'll be through your popcorn in no time.

Author: Fico Cangiano
Review: Pure monster mayhem and popcorn fun! [Full review in Spanish]

Author: Alistair Harkness
Review: A stark lesson in why not every well-connected male director with a boilerplate indie film to their name deserves a $200m budget for their sophomore feature.

Author: Jordi Costa
Review: A sophisticated sense of humor and a commitment to the purest pleasures of the pulp are allied in a film that supposes a breath of fresh air in the landscape of a contemporary blockbuster. [Full review in Spanish]

Author: Diego Batlle
Review: The film is basic in its plot, but brilliant in its concretion. The fight scenes between immense creatures reach a spectacularity and a credibility rarely seen. [Full review in Spanish]

Author: Jorge Rivera Rubio
Review: A very entertaining summer movie before the summer, which I want to see again on the biggest screen possible. [Full review in Spanish]

Author: Jim Lane
Review: Somehow it all works; there's the right blend of excitement and humor in the script (by Dan Gilroy, Max Borenstein, Derek Connolly and John Gatins) and Jordan Vogt-Roberts' lickety-split direction keeps us on the edge of our seats.

Author: Valerie Complex
Review: The movie moves along pretty quickly because it isn't bogged down by pointless human side stories the audience won't care about.

Author: Leonard Maltin
Review: This is the best monster movie I've seen in years, adding new energy and excitement to a storyline that incorporates the ingredients we all expect. It's been too long since I had such fun at a movie that promises just that

Author: Vicky Roach
Review: A clever, but not-too-clever blend of humour, action and myth.

Author: Jim Vorel
Review: What I do know, is that your enjoyment of Kong: Skull Island should not be a matter of surprise or chance. Either you want to see a CGI gorilla beat the hell out of skull reptiles, or you don't. No one is judging you.

Author: Matt Neal
Review: Skull Island is a mix of different shades of dumb - there's plenty of dumb fun, but also some groan-inducing, forehead-slapping moments of dumb.

Author: Jake Wilson
Review: Taken as a straightforward adventure movie, it's enjoyable enough.

Author: Tom Shone
Review: You'd say [Reilly] was the comic relief, except Kong: Skull Island can't seem to manage seriousness in the first place. Quit monkeying around.

Author: Kate Muir
Review: While the latest special effects are grade A, the plotting and character development is that of a B-movie. This Kong desperately needed a rescue mission to save the script from mediocrity.

Author: Francesca Rudkin
Review: Director Jordan Vogt-Roberts captures the awe and amazement of the original, but has made enough changes to stand out from previous efforts, such as John Guillermin's average 1976 remake, and Peter Jackson's handsome King Kong in 2005.

Author: Chris Knight
Review: The newest Kong reboot is a rock 'em sock 'em popcorn monster movie flick, featuring the biggest Hollywood ape to date.

Author: Max Weiss
Review: You come to Kong: Skull Island to see Kong and the film delivers. He is massive and fierce and formidable, but those moist eyes of his reveal his true sensitivity.

Author: Clint O'Connor
Review: For all of its winning ways, Kong: Skull Island features some of the most empty, underwritten characters in memory. But you probably weren't expecting that anyway from this latest attempt to cash in on the legend of the giant gorilla.

Author: Richard Roeper
Review: It's wildly entertaining and it has a sense of humor about itself - and it doesn't hurt when a great big monster movie features an A-list cast including John Goodman, Samuel L. Jackson, Brie Larson, Tom Hiddleston and John C. Reilly.

Author: Cameron Meier
Review: Lacking the novelty of the 1933 original and the style and wonder of the 2005 Peter Jackson remake, this Kong is just plain unnecessary.

Author: Roger Tennis
Review: 'Kong: Skull Island' reigns as prime matinee fare.

Author: Mark Sommer
Review: It's a fun and at times suspenseful creature adventure, with a nod to some elements of the Kong story dating back to Ernest B. Schoedsack and Merian C. Cooper's all-time 1933 classic, featuring Willis O'Brien's stop-motion animation gorilla.

Author: John Urbancich
Review: 'Kong' remains a pretty darn good popcorn movie. Just don't let any of the often gory details thrown up by this alleged "PG-13" offering get in the way of your digestive system.

Author: Chris Klimek
Review: Every time the movie threatens to get interesting, one of its hordes of ersatz, non-animated characters shows up and starts talking again.

Author: Michael Smith
Review: Kong: Skull Island works on a pure-adrenaline level of excitement, fully aware that the audience isn't here for a story, or the actors, but for the monsters and the destruction.

Author: Jake Coyle
Review: Ultimately, the film's Vietnam setting is less about warfare and history than finding an intoxicating canvas for a pretty old story. Kong: Skull Island is more about the monster clashes and, as the post-credit clip proves, setting up future installments.

Author: J.R. Kinnard
Review: Kong: Skull Island is a perfectly acceptable monster mash. Kong looks great, the action is thunderous, and any film that features John C. Reilly using a samurai sword to battle giant monsters is definitely worth seeing.

Author: Richard von Busack
Review: The witty and energetic director Jordan Vogt-Roberts corrals hallucinatory megafauna, who attack with viscera-splattering violence.

Author: Joe Morgenstern
Review: I've gone on about the creatures because there's so little to say about the humans, who, in their turn, have little to say about the creatures, because the writers haven't written enough lively dialogue.

Author: Mark Dujsik
Review: This Kong is an imposing monster, to be sure, but as an innocent caught up in the dealings of the inhabitants of a world beyond his comprehension, he doesn't quite register.

Author: Emily St. James
Review: I wish I liked Skull Island as much as I like individual moments in it.

Author: Rob Carnevale
Review: Big on spectacle but short on nuanced characterisation or coherent plotting, Kong: Skull Island is a deeply flawed but somehow still enjoyable romp that entertains in spite of its shortcomings.

Author: Katie Walsh
Review: It could have easily been titled "Apocalypse Kong" -- but it's surprisingly fun and fresh.

Author: Stephen Rebello
Review: Unfortunately, the movie never comes close to touching the... 1933 original a flat-out masterpiece. But, hey, maybe that's too much to ask... at least Skull Island hits its marks hard and fast and paves the way for much better sequels.

Author: James Berardinelli
Review: If the ultimate point of this movie is to get Kong into the ring with Godzilla, this isn't a bad appetizer.

Author: Kristian M. Lin
Review: For all the work and talent that went into it, Kong: Skull Island evaporated for me as soon as I left the theater.

Author: Norman Wilner
Review: The result is a movie that feels refreshingly unpredictable even as it works within the standard franchise parameters -- much like Gareth Edwards's Godzilla, to which it's tied only glancingly, it finds its own tone and never wavers.

Author: Frank Swietek
Review: Dutifully assembled but ultimately fails to capture the spark needed to turn it into something special.

Author: Paul Farren
Review: Despite a slim story... the effects are enough to carry this yarn. When the monsters are in the ring it is great fun to watch and there are plenty of WWF monster bouts to keep a smile on the faces of those that care.

Author: Brian Lowry
Review: Mostly, the movie gives the impression of serving as the opening salvo in a larger corporate enterprise. And while its leading man might be gigantic, in qualitative terms, Kong doesn't set the bar very high.

Author: J. R. Jones
Review: For no reason I can fathom, except perhaps the classic-rock tunes desired for the soundtrack-the story takes place in 1973, when the Vietnam war is winding down and President Nixon is being driven from office.

Author: Jon Niccum
Review: A metaphor for America's involvement in foreign wars? A contrast between the majesty of nature and the limitations of man? An argument that big is indeed better? Sort of.

Author: Leigh Paatsch
Review: It could have been an absolute calamity. Instead, you can consider this a triumphant coronation : Kong is king once more.

Author: Matthew Razak
Review: While Kong: Skull Island can get drastically stupid at times it always seems aware of this and it has figured out an antidote: Kong smash.

Author: Matt Pais
Review: This sequel/reboot/doesitevenmatteranymore preaches about a world in which monsters are real and, crucially, has the visual boom to back it up.

Author: Marc Savlov
Review: On the whole, though, Kong: Skull Island is great big dumb fun. It's also shockingly beautiful to look at when you aren't having creature guts flung into the camera.

Author: Eric Eisenberg
Review: The movie is as legitimately fun as it is thrilling, and it simultaneously generates excitement about for futures of both the giant ape and his latest director.

Author: Tony Medley
Review: An All-Star cast, great visual effects and cinematography, good pace, tight directing, and another gargantuan ape in love with a beautiful woman who can fit in the palm of his hand; what more do you want?

Author: Peter Howell
Review: This is a real Kong show, the one demanded by popcorn peddlers and munchers alike.

Author: Nigel Andrews
Review: It's fun if you check your brain at the cloakroom.

Author: Calvin Wilson
Review: If you're looking for a film that offers pure escapism, "Kong: Skull Island" should definitely meet expectations.

Author: Ann Hornaday
Review: "Kong: Skull Island" is a big, noisy B-movie infused with moments of wit and sprightly visual sophistication, anchored by what surely must be the most enormous version of King Kong since the giant ape made his screen debut in 1933.

Author: Fred Topel
Review: It sort of falls apart when we're supposed to start caring who dies. It's well-meaning to try to make them dimensional characters, but they are monster fodder.

Author: Brian Orndorf
Review: It's entertaining escapism with a giddy appreciation for creature violence and thickly sliced human motivation, delivering an idiosyncratic King Kong extravaganza that's different in many ways, while still exploiting traditional monster mayhem.

Author: Stephanie Zacharek
Review: The picture is grand and nutty and visually splendid: Vogt-Roberts knows he's gotta go big or go home, so he treads boldly ...

Author: Kenneth Turan
Review: Story and soul are never going to be kings on Skull Island, but they could have fared better than this.

Author: Matt Zoller Seitz
Review: A half-magnificent, half-misguided example of a 'show me the monster' movie.

Author: Laura Clifford
Review: With a story by John Gatins, screenwriters...have reimagined Kong as a Vietnam era anti-war movie, the film's real villain Lt. Colonel Preston Packard (Samuel L. Jackson), itching to kill after having 'abandoned' the war in Vietnam.

Author: Jason Zingale
Review: Kong: Skull Island is pure fun from start to finish, proving once again that when it comes to cinematic monsters, Kong is still king.

Author: Julian Roman
Review: Kong fans rejoice. Skull Island delivers the monster beat down exactly as promised.

Author: Rene Rodriguez
Review: Spielberg would approve. So would Ray Harryhausen.

Author: Neil Pond
Review: A jolt of super juiced-up, monster-movie energy restores some of the raw edges of wild, wooly excitement to the Kong saga while giving it a fresh new, retro-rollicking spin.

Author: Rafer Guzman
Review: An unusual combination of thunderous monster movie and gritty war film, "Kong: Skull Island" is a fresh take on a nearly 85-year-old classic.

Author: Ty Burr
Review: "Kong: Skull Island" is a Saturday afternoon monster movie, nothing more and nothing less - that's what's good about it.

Author: Manohla Dargis
Review: "Skull Island" is adept at goosing you; it deploys action-movie feints and horror-film frights capably amid its clichés and deaths. Every so often it also pauses and allows Kong and Mason to move you.

Author: Matthew Turner
Review: The script does a great job of quietly undermining the usual action clichés. And there's no tedious love story between the two nominal leads.

Author: Josh Bell
Review: From the moment Kong appears onscreen, the movie delivers near-constant action, and the island is filled with brilliantly rendered monstrosities.

Author: Moira MacDonald
Review: I'll admit to having a pretty good time at "Kong: Skull Island," helped immensely by a very large bag of popcorn ...

Author: Tim Cogshell
Review: Kong: Skull Island is pretty good popcorn cinema, but it's more of a business plan - than a movie - which involves a lot of movies of which this is only one. As for what it's about - the big pissed off monkey - is what it's about.

Author: Michael Phillips
Review: The money's on the screen, but it bought a really good movie, too.

Author: CJ Johnson
Review: Once [John C. Reilly] enters, the film gives up any pretence at being anything approaching scary and doubles down on the jokes. From then on it's a lethal tight-forty at the Skull Island Club, two-drink minimum, try the veal. Or one of the cast.

Author: Rob Hunter
Review: There's fun to be had, but it's a forgettable romp serving only to bring us one step closer to the next entry in the franchise and the cold, inevitable grip of death itself.

Author: Mikel Zorrilla
Review: A visual delight giving us pretty much everything one could expect from a movie with monsters, but has a basic story with a "development" between poor and ridiculous. [Full review in Spanish]

Author: Julie Washington
Review: While Kong delivers violence and scares, it's the film's willingness to show that its monster is also a hero that makes it one of the best spins on King Kong in a long time.

Author: Kam Williams
Review: A riveting reboot!

Author: Dann Gire
Review: Skull Island knows what makes an old-fashioned monster movie work, mainly lots of monsters. Some fly. Some swim. Some have big teeth.

Author: Dominic Corry
Review: Movies about giant monsters don't live or die on "larger points" and Kong: Skull Island remains a consistently entertaining hoot throughout.

Author: Jake Cole
Review: Every creature here that's intended to burrow themselves into the audience's nightmares are less wonders of imagination than of size.

Author: Geoffrey Macnab
Review: The pleasure of the film, directed with plenty of vigour by Jordan Vogt-Roberts, lies in its absolute refusal to take itself remotely seriously.

Author: Helen O'Hara
Review: Fatally, the director never spends time on any of the characters who fill the screen -- and while no sensible person goes to a monster movie for deep human drama, you need at least a sprinkling to make it work.

Author: Luke Y. Thompson
Review: Your inner child, if you still have one, should love it. Emphasis on the "if."

Author: Witney Seibold
Review: It's a lightning-quick, bright, dumb, slyly silly, unapologetically clichéd pulp adventure that, despite it all, is a rip-roaring good time.

Author: John Lui
Review: The production is saved by interesting action sequences and strong creature effects, but it is unfortunate that a story that tries to wrest Kong from his racist roots is as tangled as its jungle setting.

Author: Dan Mecca
Review: It's clear that Roberts is more concerned with constructing solid B-movie entertainment at an A-movie budget line than he is with character development. And that's just fine.

Author: Gary Thompson
Review: Director Jordan Vogt-Robert delivers one fresh and imaginative surprise after another, cleverly framed, nicely paced ...

Author: Brian Truitt
Review: Kong still commands respect ... his presence alone makes it worth a trip to Skull Island.

Author: Will Leitch
Review: It's no surprise that Kong: Skull Island has such dull, rote human characters (with one notable, delightful exception). But it is a shock that the ape himself is so distant and sullen.

Author: Mike Scott
Review: It's got a great ensemble cast. It's got eye-popping visual effects. It's got a blend of non-stop action and well-timed humor. In short, it's just plain fun.

Author: Bill Goodykoontz
Review: "Kong: Skull Island" is one of those movies best described as big, dumb fun.

Author: Donald Clarke
Review: The weight of influence should crush the life out of Skull Island, but the film is handled with such humour and gusto that it proves impossible to resist.

Author: Travis Hopson
Review: The shift in dynamic makes for a lot of Predator-esque monster fun, while Roberts's 1970s influences, in particular Apocalypse Now, make this Kong movie a true giant.

Author: Scott Chitwood
Review: If you love monster movies, Kong: Skull Island is required viewing on the big screen.

Author: Mick LaSalle
Review: It has a smart script, imaginative filmmaking and a cast of fine actors that actually get to act.

Author: Simon Miraudo
Review: Kong: Skull Island doesn't reinvent the wheel. It just rides it. And it's a lot of fun.

Author: James Mottram
Review: Director Jordan Vogt-Roberts strikes a fine balance between action, drama and humour.

Author: Joanna Langfield
Review: There are monsters among us. And if what you're looking for is eye popping, easily digestible escapism, you might be perfectly fine with these oh so cinematic hairy beasts.

Author: Sarah McIntyre
Review: Do we really need another Kong movie is probably the question you're asking yourself right now, but for a big-screen reboot, Jordan Vogt Roberts has managed to do the impossible -- make it seem fresh and relevant to today.

Author: Jasper Rees
Review: There is plenty of infantilising fun to be had.

Author: Kenji Fujishima
Review: Kong may be God to the humans in the film, but the only God Jordan Vogt-Roberts & co. seem genuinely interested in serving is that of The Almighty Dollar.

Author: Sandy Schaefer
Review: Kong: Skull Island is a shared universe launchpad that fulfills its promise of big, goofy, monster mayhem - setting up even bigger things to come.

Author: Steve Persall
Review: Kong: Skull Island strips the beauty from a legendary beast, reducing a classic movie star to soulless monster mechanics. Kong smashes, but not much else. Whoever dies doesn't matter. Whoever lives has a sequel promised by the end credits.

Author: Mara Reinstein
Review: This ferocious beast is the reason CGI was created!

Author: Chris Barsanti
Review: There's something already a little worn out here, like we're seeing Jurassic Park 8 without having gone through the rest of the series first.

Author: Kyle Smith
Review: The monster battles have enough wow to keep the movie rolling along, but the connective tissue is so thin that it scarcely matters who lives and who gets stomped, eaten, blown up, ripped to shreds or impaled.

Author: Peter Travers
Review: The dialogue is clunky, the A-list actors are slumming and, yeah, you've seen it all before, but the thunderously exciting creature effects make this Kong reboot a rip-roaring rumble in the jungle.

Author: Peter Canavese
Review: Builds to the fulfillment of the 'MonsterVerse' promise (further teased in a post-credits scene) of monster-on-monster action...It's all very silly...and also a kind of bruising primordial thrill ride.

Author: A.A. Dowd
Review: Ultimately more interested in gorilla warfare than the guerilla kind, Skull Island looks from a distance like a Vietnam polemic with a monster painted onto it. But the opposite is truer. It's a King Kong movie -- a state-of-the-art monster mash.

Author: Roger Moore
Review: A grating miscalculation

Author: MaryAnn Johanson
Review: Boiled down to its bonkers essence, Skull Island is a Vietnam war movie with monsters, a retro analog vibe, and a dash of both Moby-Dick and The X-Files.

Author: Emma Simmonds
Review: Quibbles fall by the wayside like toppling trees. A tantalising establisher for a clash of the titans, this ably-directed actioner is monstrously entertaining.

Author: Anthony Lane
Review: The thing that breaks the back of this movie, and makes the second half so much less prodigious than the first, is a simple matter of geography.

Author: Mark Hughes
Review: Kong: Skull Island is a fast-paced adrenaline rush that gives us lots of CGI eye candy, lots of thrilling action sequences and scary moments, lots of laughs, and lots of charismatic performers...

Author: Louise Keller
Review: Director Jordan Vogt-Roberts injects just the right tone - the perfect combo of humour, action and character, although it is no surprise that the ape at the film's centre is the ultimate scene-stealer. It's a perfect B-Movie

Author: Germain Lussier
Review: It's not going to make you think, it's not going to mess with your head, it's not going to make you consider the nature of existence, but it's an action movie that fires on all cylinders and you're going to love the hell out of it.

Author: Wilson Morales
Review: Kong: Skull Island is an exciting and visually stunning film filled with amazing special effects that should leave audiences ready to see more of this revitalized monster genre.

Author: Kristy Puchko
Review: Kong: Skull Island is a lively adventure that boasts bonkers battles and a wondrous wallop of star power from its humans and beasts alike.

Author: Amy West
Review: Regardless of its flaws, there's still a fair few things to like about Kong: Skull Island.

Author: Chris Bumbray
Review: A blast from start-to-finish that's paced with eye-candy, and features a stand-out performance by John C. Reilly.

Author: Don Kaye
Review: It's hard to say whether it will linger in your memory very long, but it will keep you glued to your seat. Sorry Godzilla, but Kong has the edge for now.

Author: Daniel Green
Review: There's little to Kong: Skull Island that isn't either hugely unnecessary or just plainly illogical.

Author: Rosie Fletcher
Review: Kong: Skull Island is an efficient, effective monster movie

Author: Travis Johnson
Review: ...that's the thing about Kong - it's never not fun...

Author: Simon Foster
Review: [A] decibel-defying mash-up of grand-scale monster movie, grunt-level military fantasy and state of the art effects showcase.

Author: Alonso Duralde
Review: Scratches your monster-movie itch without ever once providing an injection of unpredictability or eccentricity. It lacks neither fun nor polish, but it has the square tidiness of a compartmentalized fast-food meal.

Author: Chris Nashawaty
Review: We didn't come to Kong: Skull Island for the characters (well-developed or otherwise), we came for the damn dirty ape. And director Jordan Vogt-Roberts and Industrial Light and Magic's Kong is a CGI showstopper.

Author: Jonathan Hatfull
Review: Although it doesn't reach the heights of Edwards' Godzilla, Kong: Skull Island works hard to bring us something new, and it does deliver some pretty impressive punches.

Author: Chris Hunneysett
Review: Never has any version of Kong lacked such personality.

Author: Dominick Suzanne-Mayer
Review: It understands the appeal of these movies as a reminder of humanity's relative insignificance in the face of horrors it can't possibly comprehend.

Author: Heather Wixson
Review: From beginning to end, Kong: Skull Island is one geek-out moment after another, and I'm so glad that this new iteration of the iconic character gets such a glorious cinematic treatment as he does here.

Author: Chris Stuckmann
Review: Kong: Skull Island features enough frenetic monster action to satisfy some, but the whole affair can't escape a vapidly hollow feeling after the credits roll.

Author: Jim Slotek
Review: A big, dumb beast that, for all its noise, is kind of lovable at heart. That describes both a certain giant ape and Kong: Skull Island, the latest of an oeuvre of King Kong films going back 80-plus years.

Author: Clarisse Loughrey
Review: It's a film that, somehow, takes the fun out of watching a giant monkey slam-dunk a helicopter into the ground.

Author: Matt Prigge
Review: When you catch it on TV years hence, you'll watch half of it before you realize you've seen it already.

Author: Stefan Pape
Review: Thrives in its playful, irreverent approach, endearingly kitsch and gloriously overstated, with an unwavering commitment to entertainment.

Author: Terry Staunton
Review: The Kong remains the same, but director Jordan Vogt-Roberts wrangles a hugely imaginative coterie of new creatures from the lagoon, land and air to both help and hinder (mostly hinder) the luckless homo sapiens.

Author: Adam Woodward
Review: This is important to keep in mind while you're watching Tom Hiddleston: His charm is perishable.

Author: Scott Mendelson
Review: It's a visually striking, character-driven monster mash adventure. So yeah, it's pretty darn good.

Author: Bilge Ebiri
Review: A charming, insistent trifle, a monster movie that's unafraid to be cruel while also mining the genre's inherent silliness.

Author: Peter Bradshaw
Review: This fantastically muddled and exasperatingly dull quasi-update of the King Kong story looks like a zestless mashup of Jurassic Park, Apocalypse Now and a few exotic visual borrowings from Miss Saigon.

Author: Todd McCarthy
Review: All the requisite elements are served up here in ideal proportion, and the time just flies by, which can rarely be said for films of this nature.

Author: Alex Welch
Review: Kong: Skull Island is a welcome return to the silver screen for the King of the Apes.

Author: Owen Gleiberman
Review: The surprise is that Skull Island isn't just ten times as good as Jurassic World; it's a rousing and smartly crafted primordial-beastie spectacular.

Author: Kyle Anderson
Review: It's certainly not a perfect movie, and a lot of the characters feel like sketches more than full fledged people, but it roars along enjoyably from start to finish.

Author: Brian Formo
Review: [Kong: Skull Island] feels like a movie that was made in a focus group chemist lab and never solidifies an identity.

Author: George Simpson
Review: While Kong: Skull Island is let down by some of its cast, characters and scripts, it is still great fun as a crash-bang-wallop monster movie and is well worth seeing.

Author: Jordan Farley
Review: Derivative and a little dumb but consistently fun: there's personality and panache to spare in this monster blockbuster. With reservations, Skull Island is a swinging success.

Author: Joshua Rothkopf
Review: Directed by Jordan Vogt-Roberts with a gleeful, look-at-me-ma garishness that speaks to his background in TV comedy, the movie feels wonderfully close to self-parody.

Author: Jonathan Pile
Review: This is an uneven adventure that's saved by the spectacle of its towering title character and the various beasts with whom he shares his island home.

Author: Robbie Collin
Review: Imagine Steven Spielberg's The Lost World if it had been written and directed by Gremlins-era Joe Dante.

Author: Edward Douglas
Review: A popcorn movie that's only good as long as you still have popcorn left in your tub, and is quickly forgotten after you've run out.

Author: Mike Ryan
Review: Kong: Skull Island is a hoot.

Author: Drew Taylor
Review: "Kong: Skull Island" enters with lofty ambitions and style to spare. Whether or not it completely succeeds is open for subjective debate, but damn if it isn't a hell of a ride.

Author: Matt Singer
Review: Delivers a solid supply of cheap thrills.

Author: Matt Donato
Review: Kong: Skull Island is a grand cinematic adventure powered by furry fury, as the horrors of war blend with chest-beating creature confidence.
